title: AUDIT-C for Alcohol Use
description: Identifies at-risk drinkers (i.e., binge drinking) who may not be alcohol dependent. A brief 3-question alcohol screen derived from the full AUDIT questionnaire.

parameters.name: frequency
parameters.description: How often did you have a drink containing alcohol in the past year?

parameters.name: typical_drinks
parameters.description: How many drinks containing alcohol did you have on a typical day when you were drinking in the past year?

parameters.name: six_or_more
parameters.description: How often did you have six or more drinks on one occasion in the past year?

parameters.name: sex
parameters.description: Patient's biological sex (different cutoff values for males and females)

ranges.interpretation: Score suggests low risk drinking pattern
For females, score ≥3 suggests alcohol misuse
For males, score ≥4 suggests alcohol misuse

references: Bush K, Kivlahan DR, McDonell MB, Fihn SD, Bradley KA. The AUDIT alcohol consumption questions (AUDIT-C): an effective brief screening test for problem drinking. Ambulatory Care Quality Improvement Project (ACQUIP). Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test. Arch Intern Med. 1998 Sep 14;158(16):1789-95.
Bradley KA, DeBenedetti AF, Volk RJ, Williams EC, Frank D, Kivlahan DR. AUDIT-C as a brief screen for alcohol misuse in primary care. Alcohol Clin Exp Res. 2007 Jul;31(7):1208-17.

Frank D, DeBenedetti AF, Volk RJ, Williams EC, Kivlahan DR, Bradley KA. Effectiveness of the AUDIT-C as a screening test for alcohol misuse in three race/ethnic groups. J Gen Intern Med. 2008 Jun;23(6):781-7.
formula: Sum of points from three questions (0-4 points each). Total score range: 0-12 points.
notes: One standard drink equals: 12 oz beer (5% alcohol), 8 oz malt liquor (7% alcohol), 5 oz wine (12% alcohol), or 1.5 oz spirits (40% alcohol)
Higher scores correlate with greater severity of alcohol misuse
The AUDIT-C is a brief version of the 10-question AUDIT instrument
Validated in male veterans initially, later validated across diverse populations
